3. What do I need to do before the student starts the clinical practicum?

• Understand what level the student is in the program. 
• Clarify course practicum objectives and competencies, and faculty expectations. 
• “Meet” the student prior to the clinical practicum through email or phone. 
• Consider asking the student for a current resume so you can better understand the student’s background and experience. 
• Orient the student to your patient population by providing them with reading materials and resources.
4. What can I expect from the students?

• Students should complete paperwork and training required by your institution in a timely manner (e.g., immunization records, RN license, student ID, computer and EMR training). 
• Students should arrange clinical dates and times with you as soon as possible. They should work a schedule that is convenient for you. 
• Students should be punctual at the beginning of each clinical day and may not leave for the day until you approve it. 
• Professional dress and grooming are expected. 
• Students should only see patients under your direction. You should know about every patient they see, and they should ask and follow your directions about how you see this working best in your practice.

• Ensure that the clinical experience is appropriate for the student in terms of both scope of practice and the ability to meet the clinical course objectives. 
• Provide enough support for the student to feel comfortable asking questions and offering ideas. 
• This is an active learning situation. You are not there to “pour” knowledge into the student. Gently challenge the student to grow, not just regurgitate back information. Help the student make “connections: and understand how bits of information integrate to “paint the picture” of the patient and guide management. 
• Students learn by example as they observe how you handle clinical situations, decision-making and patient/family/peer relations. However, keep “observation only” to a minimum. 
• Address student’s learning challenges early to help facilitate student success. If you have concerns about the student’s progress, discuss it with the student and contact the faculty member promptly.
6. What will students expect from me?

• Students expect that you will: 
• Provide feedback on their performance and that you will promptly discuss any issues or concerns. 
• Create an optimal climate for learning. 
• Give feedback in a professional manner without demeaning or criticizing the student, especially in front of the patient or staff. 
• Consider using the “Ask, Tell, Ask” method: 
• Ask students how they think they did on a specific task. This allows reflection, they often come up with the same points you were planning to discuss. 
• Tell them how you see the situation and ways for improvement and provide specific, directed feedback. 
• Then Ask them how they will change their behavior going forward. This confirms that you agree on specific ways to improve moving forward.
7. What can I do if there are problems?

• Contact the faculty member responsible – Dr. Fowler cfowler@odu.edu for FNP students and Dr. Haney thaney@odu.edu for CNS students. 
• The faculty will actively solicit feedback about student progress during the semester. 
• The faculty will collaborate with you on any questions, issues, or concerns throughout the student’s rotation. 
• Faculty are there to provide support and guidance to you in your role, please contact the faculty member anytime there are questions or concerns.
